p.seg: Reading/studying books is (only) the second most important task for the gentlean/student. (Menneske foerst!)
Reading books is the secondary thing to do. ???? (See Li Zhi on 二義)
In fact the principles of human life are all immediately completely present
and the reason why one wants to read books>study
is presumably because as yet one has not lived through a great number of things
The sages have lived through a great many things
and therefore they have written their experience down in small volumes, for others to read.
And so when nowadays we read books
our only desire is to catch sight of these many principles.
When we have properly understood these (principles)
they turn out to be those we originally had, to start with,
they are not things that are added to us from the outside.
Study
first happens when on one's own person a crucial point gets understood.
This reading of books is already a secondary matter.
On your own person the principles/truths are all provided,
they never get added from the outside.
So, when the sages teach others,
when you need to read these books of theirs
then in my view it is that although one has these truths already
one must lived them through
only then one gets hold of them.
What the sage explains/preaches
is what he has lived through.
Study,
irrespective of one's talent or stupidity, slightness or greatness, nobility or humbleness
is naturally a matter between a man and understanding.
Moreover, if the sages and worthies had never been born,
if there weren't these many books,
if there weren't these many explanations,
that would'nt allow one not to go out and understand things!
One would still have to go and understand them!
Now, as it happens, there are the words of the sages and worthies,
and we have a lot of writings,
but still people do not go out and get to work!
Teachers and friends are only those who expound things.
If a man does not move forward himself
how can his teachers and friends bring their force to bear on him?
As for the way of conducting study
the sages and the worthies teach this to others,
and they explain it very distinctly.
In sum, when the student reads books
he must make it his business to get to the bottom (of these explanations).
"To follow the path of study" (cf. Liji, Zhongyong) is a great task
One must understand properly the principles so as to go ahead and become a person.
Generally, when it comes to reading books,
one must, having finished reading them, read them again.
Paragraph by paragraph, sentence by sentence, character by character, one must understand them,
and then, still, one must go on to check against the various interpretations and commentarialtraditions,
When the message is pervasively understood,
and this makes the principles and one's own heart be in voluntary agreement
then one has got it right.
In reading books one's own principles must be thoroughly gone through.
When reading books
one must read one volume only,
and every day one must only read one paragraph,
only then will it begin to be one's very own.
When one reads this and also reads that
even if these have passed under one's eyes once,
ultimately one is not properly familiar with them.
These days, when people read books,
when they have not yet read to a certain point,
their minds are already later in the text.
When they have just reached a certain point in their reading,
then they are inclined to leave it along.
When one proceeds like this
that is simply not to try to understand oneself,
One must hover around a passage, develop an affection for it,
and when one will not let it go,
then one can understand it.
What I most dislike people to do is to pick and choose (things to understand or interpret).
When one reads a text
one must go after each single paragraph, each sentence, and understand it.
Looking at lots of things and choosing broadly
is not as good as reading carefully and reflecting subtly.
